name: Dirichlet L-function
rephrased: The Dirichlet L-function is a complex function that generalizes the Riemann zeta function and is used to study the distribution of prime numbers in arithmetic progressions defined by a Dirichlet character.
implication_form: If the Dirichlet L-function does not vanish at s=1, then there are infinitely many primes in the arithmetic progression defined by the character.
solved_by: Peter Gustav Dirichlet (for the Dirichlet theorem on arithmetic progressions)
explained: A Dirichlet L-function is defined for a Dirichlet character χ modulo q as the analytic continuation of the L-series ∑_{n=1}^∞ χ(n)/n^s, where s is a complex variable with real part σ > 1. This function, denoted by L(s, χ), is a meromorphic function on the complex plane and generalizes the Riemann zeta function ζ(s) (which corresponds to the principal Dirichlet character modulo 1 or modulo q for q prime). It plays a crucial role in number theory, particularly in the Dirichlet density theorem, which states that any arithmetic progression containing infinitely many primes has a density (related to the Dirichlet density) proportional to 1/φ(q), and this density can be expressed using the values of L(s, χ) at s=1.
related_conjectures: Euler's conjecture (on the order of vanishing at s=1)
